Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Ultrafast and multidimensional vibrational spectroscopy of aqueous interfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this CAREER award, supported by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor John McGuire and his research group at Michigan State University will study vibrational relaxation, orientational dynamics, and couplings between vibrational modes of water at aqueous interfaces. The properties of water, such as its anomalously high boiling point and heat capacity, derive largely from its hydrogen-bond network. The properties of this network are often a product of its dynamics, which are characterized by picoseconds to sub-picosecond timescales. The termination of the hydrogen-bond network at interfaces leads to dynamics distinct from those widely measured in the bulk. However, to date, the vast majority of experimental studies of aqueous interfaces have focused on their static properties. By exciting a non-equilibrium distribution of water molecules and then measuring the surface-sensitive sum-frequency response, the surface dynamics can be probed. This offers the opportunity for new insights into the interfacial hydrogen-bond network. Professor McGuire's group will employ new multidimensional and phase-sensitive techniques for the detection of sum-frequency signals to enhance the sensitivity to weak surface nonlinear optical processes. Investigations will address the differences in the dynamical properties of a range of chemically and physically important aqueous interfaces including hydrophobic and hydrophilic interfaces and aqueous interfaces characterized by varying concentrations of solutes such as salts.


Understanding dynamics and vibrational couplings at aqueous interfaces will impact our understanding of a broad range of phenomena at aqueous interfaces, such as solvation and charge transfer, that are central to such varied processes as protein folding, electrochemical energy generation and storage, heterogeneous catalysis, and atmospheric chemistry. The techniques developed will also find application in studies of other interfacial and non-centrosymmetric bulk systems. Students involved in this project will receive training in vibrational and ultrafast spectroscopy and nonlinear optical techniques broadly applicable to studies of chemical and physical systems. Through activities such as engagement of high school teachers in research and hands-on workshops for K-12 teachers, the process and results of scientific discovery and an appreciation for a scientific understanding of water will be disseminated to students in K-12.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on understanding the dynamics of the hydrogen bond network of water at interfaces. Water is an unusual liquid. For example, at room temperature it remains a liquid even though other equally light molecules (e.g., methane) are gases at room temperature. In the bulk, each H2O molecule forms hydrogen bonds with four neighboring H2O molecules, and it is the resulting strong hydrogen bond network that gives rise to so many of water’s unusual properties. At interfaces, though, the hydrogen-bond network of water terminates. The properties of aqueous interfaces are consequently expected to be different from the bulk. One example is the fact that, the surface of water does not freeze at 0° C; a quasi-liquid layer persists until temperatures several tens of degrees below the bulk freezing temperature. Until such low temperatures, the surface of water is expected to be dynamic, with hydrogen bonds continually breaking and reforming.

Dynamic processes are of fundamental importance in all physical systems. In particular, the dynamics of hydrogen-bond breaking and formation are relevant in, for example, the reorientation of water molecules, which is in turn relevant to processes such as solvation. Given that aqueous interfaces are where many chemical and physical processes occur, it is important that we understand the dynamics of the hydrogen bond network.

To distinguish the surface of water we use a highly surface-sensitive technique: infrared-visible sum frequency generation, a second-order optical spectroscopic techniques sensitive to the breaking of inversion symmetry, as occurs at the surface of an otherwise inversion symmetric material. We have used pump-probe sum-frequency generation (SFG) in which a short (~300 fs) infrared pump pulse resonant with the OH stretch vibrations of water excites the vibrational modes of water, while a sum-frequency probe selectively measures the evolution of the OH stretch vibrations at the interface. In order to identify the timescale of molecular reorientation, we use a SFG probe with fixed polarization and then measure the pump-induced change in the SFG signal as a function of time for a pump pulse with electric field polarized in nearly the same direction as the infrared probe and then for a pump pulse with electric field perpendicular to the infrared probe polarization. By exploiting the phenomenon of total internal reflection, we were able to realize a ~20-fold improvement in the state-of-the-art for signal-to-noise ratio in measurements of dynamics at aqueous interfaces, an essential prerequisite for precise measurements of the interfacial orientational dynamics.

Water at hydrophobic interfaces and at the air-water interface exhibits only subtle differences in static spectra. However, we found that the dynamics show large differences. Specifically, we probed the dangling OH groups at the interface of water and a hydrophobic self-assembled monolayer on fused silica and found that the orientational dynamics are about 50% slower than reported at the air-water interface. With our theory collaborators, we reported in Shunhao Xiao et al., Journal of the American Chemical Society 138, 5551 (2016). The paper also established a new state-of-the-art in molecular-dynamics modeling of the dynamics at aqueous interfaces with back-to-back modeling of both the water—air and the water—hydrophobic interfaces in order to understand the fundamental reasons for the differences in reported experimental measurements of the dynamics. In brief, despite what might be suggested by a simple-minded notion of hydrophobicity as something that repels water, there are forces between the surface water molecules and the hydrophobic interface that stabilize the dangling OH configuration and thereby slow the reorientation of the dangling OH to a hydrogen-bonded configuration.

In contrast to the dangling OH groups, which are stable only at hydrophobic surfaces, the hydrogen-bonded OH groups exist at both hydrophobic and hydrophilic interfaces with water and so allow us to probe both kinds of aqueous interfaces. We have studied the influence of various solutes on the reorientation of interfacial water molecules. Extensive studies of the bulk show that the reorientation of water molecules in the first solvation shell of ions are often slowed dramatically, and in the cases of certain salts, these effects extend beyond the first solvation shell. Aqueous interfaces show strong ion-dependent changes in the static surface SFG spectrum, but the effects on actual dynamics were largely unexplored. We have carried out a wide range of measurements of surface reorientational dynamics at hydrophilic and hydrophobic interfaces using different salts. In results to be reported, we found no dramatic effects of salts on surface dynamics comparable in magnitude to the effects seen in static SFG spectra.
